justification: The review notes that “the Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (SDQ; Jourard & Lasakow, 1958) required respondents to indicate the degree and accuracy with which they had communicated various aspects of themselves to others,” illustrating the instrument used to quantify self-disclosure.

The article states that many studies “take as the dependent variable retrospective measures of sharing, such as … the Willingness to Communicate (WTC) scale (McCroskey, 1992),” explicitly linking this construct with its scale.

It explains that “Nevo, Nevo, and Derech-Zehavi (1993) developed the Tendency to Gossip Questionnaire (TGQ), in which participants indicate how frequently they transmit gossip and how much they enjoy doing so,” identifying the TGQ as the measure of gossip propensity.

measured_by: Online Privacy Concern scales developed by Buchanan et al. (2006)
justification: Discussing privacy, the authors note that “privacy-related attitudes and behaviors can be captured reliably (Buchanan, Paine, Joinson, & Reips, 2006),” referring to the established scales those authors created for measuring privacy concern.

measured_by: Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale
justification: When listing personality measures, the reference list includes “A brief version of the Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (Leary, 1983),” indicating this scale operationalizes fear of negative evaluation.
The references cite “Rosenberg self-esteem scale (RSE),” signifying that global self-esteem was assessed with the well-known Rosenberg scale.

The manuscript references “Questionnaire measures of affiliative tendency and sensitivity to rejection (Mehrabian, 1976),” showing that affiliative tendency is measured with Mehrabian’s questionnaire.
